awd_titl_txt: DDRI:  Challenges of Conducting Forensic Science in Transitional Justice Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Transitional justice has come to increasingly rely on forensic anthropology to provide objective, scientific proof of war-time violence, which can then be corroborated against witness testimonies. But in the process of assembling and interpreting data, how are forensic investigations influenced by moral and legal responsibilities? This project, which trains a graduate in methods of rigorous, empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, examines how forensic teams must juggle their legal obligations to provide material evidence for criminal trials on the one hand, and their moral responsibilities to the bereaved relatives of the deceased on the other, meanwhile maintaining standards of scientific neutrality. Furthermore, findings from this research will contribute to existing forensic science models within the United States by stressing the importance of studying patterns of skeletal trauma across individuals in cases with multiple victims, such as serial murder cases, plane crashes, and natural disasters.

New York University doctoral candidate, Jennifer Trowbridge, under the supervision of Dr. Sally Engle Merry, will conduct research on forensic investigations of war crimes' victims in Colombia. Ongoing peace talks between the Colombian state and the long-standing guerilla organization, the FARC, suggest Colombia's emergence as a country engaged in transitional justice processes. As the country moves from war to peace, increasing space is opening up for relatives of the deceased to demand the exhumation, identification, and return of their loved ones' remains. The researcher hypothesizes that in order to understand patterns of mass political violence, forensic investigations require an interaction with testimonial accounts of violence that address the complex social transformations brought about by war. The Colombian gravesite provides an ideal location to examine the interactions between forensic science investigations, legal mechanisms designed to advance democratic stability, and shifts in collective identity among communities victimized by mass violence. Such an understanding takes on particular importance given US diplomatic and financial commitments to help resolve Colombia's political strife since the beginning of "Plan Colombia" in 1999. Methods of data collection and analysis include an ethnographic investigation of forensic investigation practice through the process of preliminary investigation, exhumation, laboratory analysis, and repatriation of remains. The researcher will engage in participation observation and interviews with forensic and other state and legal investigators, organizations, and families of the deceased, as well as a textual and visual analysis of forensic case reports. Findings from this study will advance cultural anthropology and law and social sciences, particularly in the areas of forensic anthropology, biological anthropology, bioarcheology, and science and technology studies.

por.por_cntn:
This research project aims to understand how bones are made to “tell their stories” in wartime Colombia through two contrasting ways of coming to know the truth about past violent events, namely, forensic scientific accounts of death events, and testimonial narratives produced by witnesses. My research asked: How do Colombian forensic teams juggle their legal responsibilities to provide evidence for war crimes trials on the one hand, and their moral responsibilities to bring closure to victims’ bereaved relatives, on the other? How do findings from the various fields of forensic science (including anthropology, medicine, odontology, archaeology, and genetics) come together to produce a definitive account of who a body was, and how these civilians were killed? Lastly, how do family members of the deceased and disappeared convene and organize with others in similar positions in order to make demands of the state for the investigation into the presumed deaths of thier relatives?

The fieldwork research I conducted under the National Science Foundation's DDRI grant has enabled me to bring an ethnographic science and technology studies perspective to the forensic sciences – particularly forensic anthropology, forensic archaeology, and forensic genetics – within the context of mass violence. I spent twelve months living in Colombia and conducting fieldwork research in 2016, as peace accords between the Colombian government and the long-standing leftist guerilla group, the FARC, were finalized, shockingly voted down in a public referendum, and finally revised and passed in Congress. Throughout this tumultous process, I was able to follow forensic scientists, on the one hand, and relatives of the country's disappeared and deceased, on the other. The Peace Accords marked an official end to more than a half century of war within Colombia. The anticipation of the Peace Accords opened increased space for forensic teams to exhume and identify dead bodies, determine cause of death, and return remains to families for reburial.

During my fieldwork research, I gained access to the Colombian government's principal forensic institute, the National Institute for Legal Medicine and Forensic Sciences, where I spent six months observing select forensic cases. The other six months of my fieldwork research was spent working with five different civil society organizations, four of which were comprised of relatives of civilians who were killed or "disappeared" in Colombia's war, and the fifth of which is an organization that provides psychological and forensic technical support to families who are working with state authorities as they investigate the illicit deaths of their relatives. This dual approach allowed me to get inside perspectives on death, disappearance and forensic science investigations from both within the Colombian government and among civil society organizations, during a year when Colombia desperately sought to deal with its violent history and shift towards new forms of nation-making.

The analysis that I am currently putting together from the field research I conducted foregrounds forensic practice and its interactions between scientific, legal, and social spheres in Colombia. It also depicts the web of competing interests in which these practices are carried out. I seek to provide a comprehensive, impartial perspective that will encourage legal and scientific institutions, as well as smaller scale NGOs and grassroots organizations, to reassess the ways in which they create expectations for and make demands of forensic investigations. My research results will ultimately seek to encourage collaboration between different institutions involved in wartime forensic investigation, ideally leading to deeper and more open partnerships between affected groups.

My research will make broader contributions to forensic specialists and policymakers by providing concrete recommendations that create a framework for the more effective implementation of forensic science in particular postwar scenarios. It will stress the importance of incorporating social context and testimonial evidence into forensic scientific findings for reconstructing wartime patterns of violent death. As violent conflict rages on across the globe and international bodies seek to guide nations through processes of transitional justice, it is crucial to recognize the ever-increasing potential of forensic science to impact collective knowledge of violent pasts, local-level reconciliation, and postwar transitional justice processes.
